document.docAuthor: Flechtmann, Carlos H. W. & Etienne, Jean
document.masterDocTitle: On plant mites from Guadeloupe, with descriptions of four new species of Eriophyidae

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: On plant mites from Guadeloupe, with descriptions of four new species of Eriophyidae

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURE 5. Vasates caritus n. sp. AL, anterior lateral aspect of female; CGF, coxigenital area of female; D, dorsal aspect of female; GM, genitalia of male; L 1, leg I (enlarged); L 2, leg II (enlarged).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis — V. c a r i t u s n.sp. is unique in presenting the following combination of morphological characters: prodorsal shield with a pattern of a short median line on posterior one fourth of shield and one pair of admedian lines extending over entire shield length; empodium 6 ­rayed; coxae smooth; dorso­opisthosomal annuli smooth; scapular setae directed upwards
Fig. 5
AL);in a dorsoventral mounting they tend to lay backwards (
Fig. 5
D).

tr.th: or 5th from rear. Total ventral annuli 46

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5 .
Vasates caritus
n.sp.
AL, anterior lateral aspect of female; CGF, coxigenital area of female; D, dorsal aspect of female; GM, genitalia of male; L1, leg I (enlarged); L2, leg II (enlarged).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material
— female holotype ,
9 female
,
9 male
paratypes , from
Haematoxylon campechianum
L., Caesalpiniaceae, Anse Bertrand , Guadeloupe ,
23 Oct. 2003
, coll. J. Etienne, on 7 microscopic preparations.
Relation to host — vagrant on leaves.
Etymology — The specific designation caritis , from the Latin careo , ­itus , meaning be without, be deprived of, refers to the reduced prodorsal shield ornamentation.

Remarks — V. c a r i t u s n.sp. was taken from the same leaves with galls formed by
Aceria doliolum
n. sp. , which is also described in this paper.
